topics.title: Misconceptions: pain/gain vs context/outcome
topics.summary: Bob explains that Jobs-to-be-Done is often misunderstood as pain/gain, but the real driver is context and desired outcome—context makes seemingly irrational behavior rational and reveals when people will change.

topics.title: Introduction and Background
topics.summary: Lenny introduces Bob Moesta, his JTBD background, and what the episode will cover (framework basics, interviewing, examples, and applications).

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor messages for Sidebar and Merge.

topics.title: Why JTBD: hiring products for progress
topics.summary: Bob defines JTBD as people “hiring” products to make progress, and uses Snickers vs Milky Way to show how true competition is demand-side (context-driven) rather than product-category based.

topics.title: Demand comes from struggling moments, not products
topics.summary: Bob argues that struggling moments create demand; he shares SNHU’s online-learning growth story and explains why roadmaps should focus on struggles rather than fixed features.

topics.title: Context/outcome vector and “kick-ass half”
topics.summary: Bob contrasts pain/gain with context/outcome as a vector of progress, emphasizing that winning products meet customers where they are (often simpler) rather than maximizing features.

topics.title: Forces model: push/pull vs anxiety/habit
topics.summary: Bob introduces the four forces (push, pull, anxiety of the new, habit of the present) that determine switching behavior, and gives a condo-moving/storage example showing how reducing friction can boost adoption.

topics.title: Demand-side sales: align to customer buying stages
topics.summary: Using Autobooks, Bob explains tailoring sales to where customers are in their buying timeline (passive looking, active looking, deciding), splitting demos accordingly and improving conversion and cycle time.

topics.title: JTBD interviewing: story-first, clustering pathways
topics.summary: Bob outlines how to interview by extracting the full decision story (not opinions), then clustering pathways (sets of pushes/pulls/anxieties/habits) to reveal multiple conflicting jobs and guide positioning (e.g., Intercom).

topics.title: Bob’s dyslexia, writing process, and teaching
topics.summary: Bob shares his inability to read/write traditionally due to early brain injuries, how he produces books via recorded conversations, and his focus on teaching and mentoring founders and students.

topics.title: Jobs-to-be-Done for career moves and switching jobs
topics.summary: Bob discusses research on why people change jobs, debunking “luck” narratives and showing that progress (learning, challenge, balance, status) often matters more than pay; money is frequently a proxy for other needs.

topics.title: Interview tactics: who to talk to and how many
topics.summary: Bob recommends interrogation-style techniques (e.g., Chris Voss), interviewing people who already tried to make progress (including competitor users), and doing ~10–12 interviews per round to find repeating causal patterns.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor message for Eppo experimentation platform.

topics.title: Lightweight JTBD: start with stories and churn
topics.summary: Bob explains how founders can begin: interview recent buyers about the decision story (functional/emotional/social energy) and interview churned users to understand changing context and switching triggers.

topics.title: Signals of real switching: beyond complaints
topics.summary: Bob warns that stated intent is unreliable (“Bitchin’ ain’t switchin’”), describes peeling back layers of language to uncover true causality, and explains value as a start-to-end vector that can be overshot by overbuilding.

topics.title: Zero-to-one challenge: JTBD examples and approach
topics.summary: Responding to skepticism, Bob frames JTBD as hypothesis-building for new products, cites examples (Autobooks, Techstars companies), and advises interviewing users of what you want them to stop using (the “fired” alternatives).
